name: St. Peter
summary: Simon Peter, also known as Cephas, was one of the Twelve Apostles of Jesus Christ and the first Bishop of Rome (Pope). He is traditionally considered the leader of the apostles and the foundation of the Church. According to tradition, he was martyred in Rome by crucifixion, upside down at his own request.
keyQuotes: You are the Christ, the Son of the living God.
Lord, to whom shall we go? You have the words of eternal life.

name: St. Paul

locations.description: Conversion on the road to Damascus

summary: Paul the Apostle, originally known as Saul of Tarsus, was a major figure in the spread of Christianity throughout the Roman Empire. After his dramatic conversion on the road to Damascus, he became the 'Apostle to the Gentiles' and wrote many of the New Testament epistles. He was martyred in Rome by beheading.
keyQuotes: I have been crucified with Christ. It is no longer I who live, but Christ who lives in me.
For I am convinced that neither death nor life... will be able to separate us from the love of God.

name: St. Stephen
summary: Stephen was one of the first seven deacons chosen by the apostles to serve the early Christian community in Jerusalem. He is venerated as the first Christian martyr, stoned to death for his faith. His martyrdom is recorded in the Acts of the Apostles, and his dying words echo those of Christ on the cross.
keyQuotes: Lord, do not hold this sin against them.

name: St. James the Great
summary: James, son of Zebedee, was one of the Twelve Apostles and the brother of John the Evangelist. He was the first apostle to be martyred, beheaded by King Herod Agrippa I in Jerusalem around 44 AD. He is the patron saint of Spain, where his remains are said to be enshrined in Santiago de Compostela.

name: St. Mark the Evangelist

locations.description: Founder and first Bishop of Alexandria

summary: Mark the Evangelist is traditionally credited with writing the Gospel of Mark, the earliest of the four canonical gospels. He is also considered the founder of the Church of Alexandria and its first bishop. According to tradition, he was martyred in Alexandria.

name: St. Barnabas
summary: Barnabas was an early Christian disciple and missionary companion of Paul the Apostle. He was instrumental in introducing Paul to the apostles in Jerusalem and later accompanied him on missionary journeys. He is considered an apostle and is traditionally said to have been martyred in Cyprus.

name: St. Luke the Evangelist
summary: Luke the Evangelist is traditionally credited with writing the Gospel of Luke and the Acts of the Apostles. He was a physician and a companion of Paul the Apostle on his missionary journeys. His gospel emphasizes the universal nature of Christ's mission and includes many details about women and the poor.

name: St. John the Evangelist
summary: John the Evangelist, also known as John the Beloved Disciple, was one of the Twelve Apostles and the author of the Gospel of John, three epistles, and the Book of Revelation. He was the only apostle not to be martyred, living to an old age in Ephesus. He is traditionally identified as the 'disciple whom Jesus loved.'
keyQuotes: In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word was God.
God is love, and whoever abides in love abides in God, and God abides in him.

name: St. Andrew
summary: Andrew was one of the Twelve Apostles and the brother of Simon Peter. He was the first disciple called by Jesus and is known for bringing his brother Peter to Christ. According to tradition, he was martyred by crucifixion on an X-shaped cross (St. Andrew's Cross) in Patras, Greece. He is the patron saint of Scotland, Russia, and Greece.

name: St. Philip
summary: Philip was one of the Twelve Apostles. He is mentioned in the Gospel of John as bringing Nathanael (Bartholomew) to Jesus. According to tradition, he preached in Asia Minor and was martyred by crucifixion in Hierapolis. He is often depicted with a cross or loaves of bread, referencing his question to Jesus about feeding the five thousand.
keyQuotes: Lord, show us the Father, and it is enough for us.

name: St. Bartholomew
summary: Bartholomew, also known as Nathanael, was one of the Twelve Apostles. He is identified in the Gospel of John as Nathanael, whom Philip brought to Jesus. According to tradition, he preached in India and Armenia, where he was martyred by being flayed alive and then beheaded. He is the patron saint of tanners and is often depicted holding a knife or his own skin.
keyQuotes: Can anything good come out of Nazareth?

name: St. Thomas
summary: Thomas, also known as Didymus (the Twin), was one of the Twelve Apostles. He is best known for doubting the Resurrection until he saw and touched the wounds of the risen Christ, earning him the nickname 'Doubting Thomas.' According to tradition, he preached the Gospel in India, where he was martyred by being speared to death. The ancient Christian communities of India trace their origins to his mission.

name: St. Matthew
summary: Matthew, also known as Levi, was a tax collector before becoming one of the Twelve Apostles. He is traditionally credited with writing the Gospel of Matthew, which emphasizes Jesus' fulfillment of Old Testament prophecies. According to tradition, he preached in Ethiopia and was martyred there. He is often depicted with a money bag or writing implements, symbolizing his former profession and his role as an evangelist.

name: St. James the Less
summary: James the Less, also known as James the son of Alphaeus, was one of the Twelve Apostles. He is sometimes identified with James, the brother of the Lord, who became the first bishop of Jerusalem. According to tradition, he was martyred by being thrown from the pinnacle of the Temple in Jerusalem and then stoned to death. He is often depicted with a fuller's club, the instrument of his martyrdom.

name: St. Jude Thaddeus
summary: Jude, also known as Thaddeus or Lebbaeus, was one of the Twelve Apostles. He is the author of the Epistle of Jude in the New Testament. He is often confused with Judas Iscariot, which may explain why he became the patron saint of lost causes and desperate situations. According to tradition, he preached in Mesopotamia and Persia, where he was martyred. He is the patron saint of hospitals and desperate cases.

name: St. Matthias
summary: Matthias was chosen by lot to replace Judas Iscariot as one of the Twelve Apostles, as recorded in the Acts of the Apostles. He had been a follower of Jesus from the beginning of his ministry. According to tradition, he preached in Judea and then in Ethiopia, where he was martyred. He is the patron saint of carpenters and tailors.

name: St. Linus
summary: Linus was the second Bishop of Rome, succeeding St. Peter. According to early Church tradition, he was ordained by Peter and Paul. He is mentioned by name in 2 Timothy 4:21. His pontificate occurred during a period of persecution under Emperor Nero, and he is traditionally considered a martyr.

name: St. Anacletus
summary: Anacletus, also known as Cletus, was the third Bishop of Rome. He is traditionally credited with ordaining priests and establishing parishes in Rome. He is mentioned in the Roman Canon of the Mass. According to tradition, he was martyred during the reign of Domitian.

name: St. Clement of Rome

locations.description: Third or fourth Bishop of Rome

summary: Clement of Rome, also known as Pope Clement I, was one of the Apostolic Fathers and an early bishop of Rome. He is best known for his First Epistle to the Corinthians, one of the earliest Christian documents outside the New Testament. According to tradition, he was martyred by being tied to an anchor and thrown into the sea.
keyQuotes: Let us be humble, therefore, brethren, laying aside all arrogance and conceit and folly and anger.
